intro: Lastrea palustris, commonly known as the marsh hound or marsh bell, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and opposite, oval-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple, arranged in whorls along the stem. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in swampy areas and along the edges of ponds. Lastrea palustris is an important component of wetland ecosystems, providing habitat and nectar for various pollinators.
